With the rise in household computing power and the increasing number of smart devices, more and more residents are able to participate in demand response (DR) management through the home energy management system (HEMS). However, HEMS has encountered challenges in developing the most effective energy management strategies, including the complexity of modeling user comfort, uncertainty in electricity price and photovoltaic (PV) output, and the challenge of solving high-dimensional time-coupled decision problems. To address these challenges, a novel data-driven deep reinforcement learning (DRL)-base HEMS optimization framework considering uncertain household parameters is proposed. Firstly, a thermal comfort evaluation model based on integrated learning is proposed. Then, a prediction model based on the bidirectional gated recurrent unit neural network (BiGRU-NN) algorithm is proposed to mine the time series PV output and electricity price data. Finally, combining the PV output and electricity price forecasting, along with the thermal comfort evaluation, an optimal decision-making method based on soft actor-critic (SAC) algorithm for the HEMS is established. The results of numerical experiments show that the proposed method can effectively solve the high-dimensional integrated decision-making problem with uncertainty. By participating in DR, the household electricity cost can be reduced by 17.7% and the total cost can be reduced by 8.4%. Furthermore, the comparison result shows that the method proposed in this paper performs better than the existing optimization models based on proximal policy optimization (PPO) algorithm and twin-delayed depth deterministic policy gradient (TD3) algorithm. Reducing peak power loads can effectively delay power system investments, enhance renewable energy usage, and aid in reducing carbon emissions while promoting environmentally sustainable development [1]. Research on integrated energy systems, home energy systems, and other related fields is on the rise, promoting the consumption of renewable energy sources and enhancing energy utilization efficiency [2,3]. The smart grid integrates advanced communication, sensing, measurement and control technologies to create a power grid with two-way transmission of power and data flow. The realization of smart grid is conducive to increasing the efficiency of power generation and use, improving the reliability of power system, promoting the participation of users in the electricity market, and reducing environmental impact [4]. Building energy consumption occupies a considerable proportion in the total energy consumption, causing an increasing burden on the power system [5,6]. Due to the development of microprocessors, huge amount of computing power has been embedded in smart devices. As a component of smart grid energy consumption side, smart homes are increasingly important in the development of modern power and energy systems. Residents are encouraged to participate in the electricity market through demand response (DR) management, utilizing their computing power and smart devices [7]. Artificial intelligence (AI) technology can analyze data from smart homes to achieve specific goals such as minimizing resource consumption, maximizing the safety and/or comfort for residents [8]. DR can help the residents rationalize their electricity consumption plans and optimize the allocation of demand-side resources; therefore, it will be able to reduce the electricity cost of users, improve system stability, and minimize the aggregated generation cost of energy suppliers. Current DR management can be divided into two main categories: incentive-based demand response (IBDR) and price-based demand response (PBDR). Related studies have shown that the energy management of smart homes can reduce the peak and valley of the power grid and reduce user costs [9]. 1.2 Related works Presently, the accurate DR modeling of multiple household devices, effective processing of uncertainties and high-dimensional comprehensive decision-making methods are the main challenges in HEMS researches [10]. A stochastic dynamic programming for HEMS based on electric vehicle (EV) energy storage was proposed in [11]. It aimed to minimize the cost of electricity for residential users, while meeting household electricity demand and EV charging requirements. A HEMS method including photovoltaic (PV) panels, energy storage system (ESS) and controllable electrical devices was proposed in [12], which used differential dynamic programming algorithm to reduce the cost of power consumption in the home and absorb as much renewable energy as possible. A novel HEMS method without changing the user's behavior was proposed in [13]. First, the residents' electricity behavior was learned, then the ESS and renewable energy source (RES) were controlled based on the user's behavior knowledge to minimize the daily energy cost. Considering PBDR, a smart home system was proposed in [14], composed of RES, battery ESS and EV, which realized the trade-off between electricity payment and consumer discomfort. A new hybrid robust multi-objective HEMS was developed in [15], which obtained a scheduling method unaffected by uncertainty, while considering the economy and comfort of the home. A novel multi-level optimization method considering uncertain parameters was proposed for green buildings in [16]. In terms of the related household appliance models, there are six main types, including non-schedulable appliance [17], power-schedulable appliance (Heating, Ventilation and Air Conditioning, HVAC) [18], time-schedulable appliance [19], EV [20], ESS [18], and PV [21]. However, it is usually assumed that each device works independently, does not share information, and does not consider the flexible coordination mechanism between multiple appliances. User's comfort is a crucial evaluation index in assessing the effectiveness of the HEMS scheduling. However, traditional thermal comfort modeling only considers temperature factors and ignores other environmental factors [22], which can lead to inaccuracies in the results and the user's subjective feeling. Thermal comfort is a subjective feeling that humans have towards their surrounding environment and can be influenced by many factors. These factors can be roughly divided into two categories: external environmental factors such as temperature, humidity, wind speed, etc.; and human factors such as human body metabolic rate, age, sex, etc. Predicted Mean Vote (PMV) is a commonly-used reference index for the assessment of thermal comfort conditions, which considers the air temperature, mean radiant temperature, relative humidity, air flow velocity, metabolic rate and clothing insulation. However, as some of these parameters contained in PMV are difficult to measure, it may lead to inaccuracies in PMV. And PMV does not take into account the subjective feelings of users. Regarding handling uncertainties in HEMS, such as electricity price and PV output, many researchers have proposed corresponding methods, such as the auto-regressive model [23], the exponential smoothing model [24], and the polynomial regression algorithm [25], etc. However, these methods are often inadequate for effectively predicting the nonlinear time-series data required in HEMS. In recent years, deep learning (DL) algorithms have developed rapidly and demonstrated powerful capabilities in time-series data prediction in power system field, and may become a potential solution for addressing the challenge of uncertain information processing in HEMS [26]. Common DL algorithms, such as gate recurrent unit (GRU) [27] and long short-term memory (LSTM) [28], have been used to predict time-series data. Artificial neural network is used to predict users' comfort temperature and other information to improve the performance of HEMS in [29]. Multiheaded convolutional neural network (CNN) is used to predict solar irradiance and wind speed in [30]. But these models can only consider one-way information flow and cannot fully mine the two-way information to make more accurate predictions. In terms of decision-making methods, traditional optimization algorithms such as convex programming with L1 regularization [31], mixed integer linear programming (MILP) [32], and stochastic dynamic optimization [11], have been applied to HEMS. However, traditional algorithms are always ineffective in solving the high-dimensional comprehensive decision-making problems with uncertainties in HEMS. In recent years, deep reinforcement learning (DRL) algorithms have also been used in HEMS, benefiting from their strong nonlinear fitting ability. DRL algorithms can be divided into three types according to their optimization strategies: value-based algorithm, policy-based algorithm and actor-critic-based algorithm. The value-based algorithm adopts an iterative strategy of value update and needs to compare the value function of each action, which makes this method difficult handle high-dimensional continuous space problems and random strategy problems [33]. The policy-based algorithm can solve the problem of high-dimensional and continuous space, but it needs a complete state sequence when updating, making it inefficient and time-consuming with poor convergence performance [34]. The actor-critic-based algorithm combines the advantages of value-based algorithm and policy-based algorithm. It uses the value function to estimate the return value, uses the estimated return value to estimate the policy gradient and then updates the parameters of the strategy [35,36]. The DRL algorithm combines the perception ability of the DL algorithm and the decision-making ability of reinforcement learning algorithm, making it a more powerful AI method for solving complex problems [37]. Aiming at stabling the building energy system and battery safety, two DRL algorithms are applied for the optimization for off-grid renewable building energy system in [38]. A transfer DRL based domestic energy management system is proposed in [39] to reduce training time and data requirements related to different household settings. The change in price information and load demand was modeled as a Markov decision process in [40], thus treating the interaction between users as a partially observable random game. A DRL-based load model was proposed in [41] to adaptively respond to the changing environment. However, few studies have integrated DRL with factors such as uncertain electricity price, uncertain PV output, and uncertain comfort models, limiting the full utilization of the data-driven and environment uncertainty handling capabilities of DRL. A hierarchical energy management system for smart homes was proposed in [42], which first performed scenario analysis for residential PV output, and then conducted a two-stage energy management according to the generated solar power generation scenario set. Afterwards, a smart home model that considers the adjustable air-water heat pump, PV system, ESS and heat storage system was proposed, and the MILP problem was transformed into a DRL problem for solution. 1.3 Contributions and organization In view of the randomness and uncertainty of information such as real-time electricity price, PV output and user's comfort evaluation, this paper proposes a novel data-driven HEMS optimization framework that integrates the residential power generation, consumption and storage devices and conducts the personalized scheduling of various types of household appliances. The main contributions are as follows: 1) Mathematical models are systematically formulated for various household appliances, based on their operational characteristics, enabling the intelligent HEMS agent to effectively coordinate and dispatch them. These models allow the HEMS to optimize the allocation of residential power resources under DR management, while considering the personalized preferences of energy users. 2) A thermal comfort evaluation model based on the XGBoost algorithm is designed to provide more accurate user comfort information for HEMS, encompassing both external environmental conditions and internal operating characteristics. 3) A prediction model based on the BiGRU-NN algorithm is proposed, which incorporates two-way information to manage the inherent randomness and uncertainties of electricity price and PV output. 4) A decision-making method based on the soft actor-critic (SAC) algorithm for the HEMS is proposed, considering the time-coupling constraints and the optimal scheduling requirements of household appliances. By integrating thermal comfort evaluation, electricity price prediction, and PV output prediction, this approach can adeptly tackle the environmental uncertainties, while elevating the overall resilience of the HEMS framework. The data-driven HEMS framework is shown in Fig. 1 . The HEMS agent get predicted price and PV output from BiGRU-NN model and the predicted thermal comfort from the XGBoost model. Then the optimal scheduling is made according to the SAC algorithm. This paper is organized as follows. In Section 2, the detailed mathematical formulation of HEMS considering the thermal comfort evaluation based on the XGBoost algorithm is presented. The data-driven HEMS framework based on BiGRU-NN algorithm and SAC algorithm is proposed in Section 3. Section 4 conducts the case studies based on real-world data. Finally, conclusions are presented in Section 5. 2 Mathematical formulation of HEMS considering the thermal comfort evaluation Multiple types of household appliances considered in this research are shown in Fig. 2 , including non-schedulable appliance, time-schedulable appliance, HVAC, EV, ESS, and PV. The basic modeling assumptions in the HEMS are as follows: 1) The study does not consider the interaction between the home equipped with HEMS and the real time price (RTP) market, and thus the users will not have knowledge of the electricity prices in advance; 2) This study does not consider the costs of power appliances and other related auxiliary devices (such as information system), and we focus only on the daily operational cost. 2.1 Basic thermal comfort evaluation indices In this study, we will use the performance of the PMV model as a benchmark to assess the established thermal comfort evaluation model. The PMV index proposed by Fanger is the most representative way [43], to assess thermal comfort, considering six influencing factors: air temperature, average radiance, relative humidity, air flow rate, human body metabolic rate, and clothing insulation. The PMV can be calculated by the following formula: (1) PMV = 0.303 e − 0.036 M body + 0.028 H C − H E − H L − q R − q C Where M body is the metabolic rate of human body, H C is the production of body heat, H E is the evaporative heat loss, H L is the heat loss of breathing, q R is the radiant heat loss, q C is the convective heat loss. Considering subjective nature of user feeling in thermal conditions, the variables used by PMV may not fully describe user comfort. In the ASHRAE standard [44], many factors are invited to evaluate the users' satisfaction under different thermal conditions, and the PMV shown in Table 1 is used as a reference scale of thermal sensation. Therefore, this research utilizes ASHRAE standard as a reference for assessing human thermal comfort and optimizing scheduling strategies. The factors taken into consideration include: metabolic rate, gender, wind speed, clothing insulation, age, relative humidity, and temperature. 2.2 Thermal comfort evaluation model based on integrated learning The thermal comfort evaluation model is used to guide the work of HVAC by ensuring indoor temperatures are neither too high nor too low, which helps save energy. If the accuracy of the model is too poor, it can lead to energy waste. While many scholars have studied the prediction of thermal comfort using machine learning, the quality of data affects the prediction results [45]. Numerical results indicate that the integrated learning performs better in thermal comfort evaluation [46]. XGBoost (eXtreme Gradient Boosting) is an integrated learning method [47]. Its main idea is to assemble a series of weak learners into a strong learner. XGBoost method first employs a set of classification and regression trees (CART) as weak learners, and then enhances the trees' performance by creating a new set of trees that minimizes the regularization objective function to reduce the variance of the model and prevent overfitting. Therefore, XGBoost algorithm can be used to evaluate the thermal comfort. The objective function of XGBoost model can be expressed as follows: (2) Obj = ∑ i = 1 n l y i y ̂ i + ∑ t = 1 K Ω f t Where y i is the real data value, y ̂ i is the predicted data value, n is the number of training data, l y i y ̂ i is the loss function, usually the square loss function, f t is the t ‐ th tree model, Ω f t is the regularization of the t ‐ th tree model. The predicted data value y ̂ i is calculated through the K tree models with input x : (3) y ̂ i = ∑ t = 1 K f t x i The regularization of each tree includes the regularization term of leaf subtrees and the regularization term of the leaf nodes, calculated as: (4) Ω f t = γ T leaf + λ ∑ j = 1 T leaf w j 2 Where γ is the penalty regularization term of leaf subtrees, T leaf is the number of tree leaf nodes, λ is the regularization term of leaf weight, w is the weight of the leaf. XGBoost adopts the additive training method of optimizing the objective function step by step. First, it optimizes the first decision regression tree, and then trains the second tree according to the prediction residual of the first tree. In this way, the target function of the k ‐ th tree can be calculated as follows: (5) Obj k = ∑ i = 1 n l y i y ̂ i t − 1 + f i x i + ∑ t = 1 k Ω f t 2.3 HEMS optimization model 2.3.1 Modeling of HEMS appliances with different electrical characteristics The optimization goal of HEMS is to minimize the power consumption costs and the aging of some specific electrical appliances while ensuring the user's demand. Thus, the objective of the HEMS can be modeled as follows: (6) min ∑ t = 1 T r t Pr ice + r t Comf Where T is the total simulation time, r t Pr ice is the electricity cost, r t Comf is the comfort cost. In Eq. (6), the coefficients of both electricity cost and comfort cost are 1, which means that users consider both costs equally important. To make one of the costs smaller, users can simply increase the coefficient of the corresponding cost and decreases the coefficient of the other cost. The electricity charge refers to the transaction cost between the HEMS and power grid or the utility company, and the total household load demand at time t is P t Grid , given by: (7) P t Grid = ∑ i = 1 N ns P i , t F + ∑ j = 1 N s P j , t S + P t HVAC + P t EV , ch − P t EV , dch + P t ESS , ch − P t ESS , dch − P t PV Where P i , t F is the demand of i ‐ th non-schedulable load, N ns is the number of non-shiftable appliances, P j , t S is the demand of j ‐ th time-schedulable load, N s is the number of time-schedulable appliances, P t HVAC is the power demand of HVAC at time t , P t EV , ch , P t EV , dch are the charging and discharging power of EV, P t ESS , ch , P t ESS , dch are the charging and discharging power of ESS at time t , P t PV is the output of PV. Since users can either purchase electricity from the grid or sell surplus electricity to the grid, the benefits of users are as follows: (8) r t Pr ice = ρ t P t Grid Δ t Where ρ t is the electricity price at time t , Δ t is the scheduling interval, and in this research Δ t = 1 . The comfort cost r t Comf refers to the penalty cost at time t in user behavior caused by DR management, which can be calculated as follows: (9) r t Comf = ∑ j = 1 N s u j , t S + u t HVAC + u t ESS + u t EV Where u j , t S is the comfort cost of the j th time-schedulable load at time t , u t HVAC is the thermal comfort cost of the HVAC at time t , u t ESS is the comfort cost of ESS at time t , and u t EV is the comfort cost of household EV at time t . Different appliances have different operational constraints, and the degree of comfort they provide will be different. S is the state space, A is the action space, P is the transition probability, R is the reward function, γ is the discount coefficient which is between 0 and 1. In this paper, we set the intelligent agent as the HEMS agent, and the environment is the whole house including various electrical appliances. The key variables of the Markov decision process for the proposed HEMS framework are shown in Table 2 . The state is P set F P set S T t − 1 HVAC T t out SOC t − 1 EV SOC t − 1 ESS P t , pre PV ρ t , the action is P t F P t S P t HVAC P t EV , ch P t EV , dch P t ESS , ch P t ESS , dch P t PV and the reward is − r t Pr ice + r t Comf . 3 DRL-based HEMS optimization framework In this section, a novel data-driven HEMS optimization framework that considers the uncertain household parameters is proposed. A new BiGRU-NN prediction model is developed to forecast the electricity prices and PV outputs. Based on the HEMS Markov decision process modeling and thermal comfort evaluation in section 2, a decision-making method using SAC algorithm is proposed to solve the complex home energy optimal scheduling problem. 3.1 Prediction model based on BiGRU-NN algorithm Neural networks are effective in dealing with the nonlinearity between features [48], and are widely used in PV forecasting and electricity price forecasting. However, most existing prediction methods only use the past information and current inputs. BiGRU-NN can utilize both forward and backward information, allowing it to more fully capture the time dependencies in time series data [49]. The GRU block consists of the reset gate r t , update gate z t , candidate unit h ˜ t and hidden unit h t , which can be calculated by (29)–(32), respectively, and wherein W r , U r , W z , U z , W and U are the weight matrices. The reset gate focuses more on capturing the short-term information features, while the update gate is better at capturing longer-term information features. As the output of the GRU block, the hidden unit h t contains both information features. (29) r t = σ W r x t + U r h t − 1 (30) z t = σ W z x t + U z h t − 1 (31) h t ∼ = ϕ Wx t + U r t ⊙ h t − 1 (32) h t = z t h t − 1 + 1 − z t h ∼ t The final output unit h t o of the BiGRU algorithm is calculated by (33) and is jointly determined by the forward propagating GRU hidden unit h → t and backward propagating GRU hidden unit h ← t , wherein γ t and φ t are the output weights, and b t is the bias. (33) h → t = GRU x t h → t − 1 h ← t = GRU x t h ← t − 1 h t o = γ t h → t + φ t h ← t + b t The prediction model based on the BiGRU-NN algorithm is shown in Fig. 3 . Firstly, the original data is preprocessed in the input layer. Then, the BiGRU layer is used to extract the potential bidirectional features of the time-series data. Finally, the last deep neural network layer is used to extract the features and output the final prediction results. For the electricity price forecasting, the input data X 1 includes the historic electricity price ρ = ρ t − 48 ρ t − 47 ⋯ ρ t − 1 in the past 48 h, the corresponding month M (e.g., integer values of 1, 2, …, 12), date D (e.g., integer values of 1, 2, …, 31), hour K (e.g., integer values of 0, 2, …, 23), week number W (e.g., integer values of 1, 2, …, 52), and the holiday sign H (with an Boolean value of 0 or 1). The input data X 1 for electricity price forecasting consists of 51 dimensions. For the PV output forecasting, the input data X 2 consists of the meteorological data from weather stations and the household historical PV generation data. In more detail, it includes the PV output in the past 48 h P t − 48 PV P t − 47 PV ⋯ P t − 1 PV , the month M , the date D , the hour K , the solar zenith angle sza t − 48 sza t − 47 ⋯ sza t − 1 , the extraterrestrial irradiance etr t − 48 etr t − 47 ⋯ etr t − 1 , the global horizontal irradiance ghi t − 48 ghi t − 47 ⋯ ghi t − 1 , the wind speed ws t − 48 ws t − 47 ⋯ ws t − 1 , and the temperature tem t − 48 tem t − 47 ⋯ tem t − 1 . The input data X 2 for PV output forecasting consists of 291 dimensions. 3.2 Decision-making method based on SAC algorithm The general interactive process of a DRL algorithm is as follows: at every time, the agent observes the state of the environment and selects an action based on that state. The agent then executes the action, and the environment transitions from the current state to the next state. During this process, the agent receives a reward value from the environment. The agent then repeats the cycle of observing the state, selecting and executing an action until the end of the process. The goal of the agent is to maximize the overall return during this process. The SAC [50] algorithm used in this paper is a DRL algorithm based on the actor-critic architecture, and its structural diagram is shown in Fig. 4 . In SAC algorithm, the policy network (actor) outputs actions, and the value network (critic) evaluates the quality of the actions selected by the actor. Compared to the deep deterministic policy gradient (DDPG) algorithm that is also an actor-critic-based DRL algorithm, the SAC algorithm uses the method of maximizing entropy to make the actions more distributed, improving the stability and efficiency of training. SAC algorithm introduces additional entropy into learning objective, defined as: (34) H P = E x ∼ P − log P x Where x follows the distribution of P . The optimal policy function of the SAC algorithm is expresses as: (35) π max ∗ = arg max π ∑ t = 0 T E s t a t ∼ ρ π r s t a t + αH π ⋅ s t Where π is the policy of the actor, r s t a t is the reward under state s t and action a t , H π · s t is the entropy of current policy π , α is the temperature coefficient that represents the relative importance of entropy to the reward. Define Q soft s t a t as the soft Q-value of the SAC algorithm under the state s t and action a t , it can be calculated as: (36) Q soft s t a t = r s t a t + γ E s t + 1 , a t + 1 V θ ′ s t + 1 (37) V θ ′ s t + 1 = Q soft s t + 1 a t + 1 − α log π a t + 1 s t + 1 Where γ ∈ 0 1 is the discount factor, V θ ′ s t + 1 is the state value function. The soft Q-value network parameters can be updated by: (38) Q soft ′ s t a t ← Q soft s t a t + lr r s t a t + γ E s t + 1 , a t + 1 Q soft s t + 1 a t + 1 − α log π a t + 1 s t + 1 Where lr is the learning rate. To avoid overestimation when maximizing Q values and further overestimation when computing the target using the Q-value network, the SAC algorithm introduces two online networks with parameters θ i i = 1 2 and two target networks with parameters θ i ′ i = 1 2 for the critic framework. And the minimum function value of the target networks' output will be finally taken as the target value. The online critic network parameter θ i can be trained by minimizing the following formula: (39) J Q θ = E s t a t ∼ D 1 2 Q θ s t a t − Q soft s t a t 2 The parameters of the target critic network are updated by the following formula with update factor τ . (40) θ i ′ ← τθ i + 1 − τ θ i ′ The flowchart of the proposed SAC-based HEMS optimization method considering uncertainty is shown in Fig. 5 . The method first uses historical data to train the thermal comfort evaluation model and the electricity price and PV prediction models. Combining these models, the DRL algorithm is trained to obtain the optimal energy use strategy for HEMS through step-by-step iteration. In order to improve the efficiency of the algorithm training, experience replay is used to store the data of each training step into the replay buffer. During training, a set of data is randomly sampled from the replay buffer for training, in this paper, the size of replay buffer is 1e6 and 256 sets of data are sampled each time. 4 Case studies Case studies are conducted as follows to validate the proposed data-driven DRL-based HEMS optimization method in this paper. Firstly, the evaluation results of thermal comfort are studied, and the influence of different features on thermal comfort is analyzed. Then, the accuracy of the BiGRU-NN prediction model is demonstrated. Finally, the optimal energy scheduling of household HEMS is conducted. 4.1 Thermal comfort evaluation results of the XGBoost model For the prediction of the thermal comfort, the ASHRAERP-884 project data set [51] is used to train and validate our proposed model. A total of 6143 samples have been preprocessed, with 80% of the data used for training, and 20% for testing. In addition, the prediction accuracy of our XGBoost-based algorithm is also compared with that of the traditional simple machine learning algorithms (such as support vector regression (SVR), and K-nearest neighbor (KNN)), deep learning algorithm (such as deep neural network (DNN)), and integrated learning algorithms (such as lightweight gradient hoist (LightGBM), and random forest (RF)), etc. Table 3 compares of thermal comfort evaluation errors of different prediction algorithms. It can be seen that the prediction results of XGBoost-based algorithm outperform other algorithms in terms of mean absolute error (MAE) and root mean square error (RMSE) indicators. By using the number of times features in the XGBoost algorithm appear as split nodes in all lifting trees as an indicator, the importance of each feature that affects human thermal comfort prediction can be ranked. It can be seen from Fig. 6 that various features play a certain role in predicting human thermal comfort, but no feature plays a decisive role, which is also the reason for the difficulty and low prediction accuracy of human thermal comfort prediction. 4.2 Performance of the BiGRU-NN prediction model In this part, we evaluate the performance of the proposed BiGRU-NN prediction model against different benchmark algorithms, including basic deep learning algorithms (e.g., LSTM, GRU) and some latest proposed algorithms (e.g., BiLSTM [52], rTPNN [53], CNN_LSTM [54]). In this study, we utilized a dataset comprising electricity price [55] and PV output data collected from the University of Oregon over the period of one year. To evaluate the performance of our model, we selected the data from March, June, September, and December for testing, while the remaining monthly data is used for training. The mean absolute errors (MAEs) of all prediction algorithms are given in Table 4 . It can be clearly seen from Table 4 that the MAE of the proposed BiGRU-NN prediction model is lower than those of the comparison methods, for both of the electricity price and PV output forecasting. The comparison results of electricity price forecast and the PV output are shown in Fig. 7 and Fig. 8 . Meanwhile, in order to investigate the impact of prediction accuracy on the decision-making process, the optimization results of the proposed decision-making method under different prediction errors (e.g., MAPE = 0%, 10%, 20%, etc.) are explored, as shown in Fig. 9 . It can be clearly seen that as the prediction error increases, the operating cost of the HEMS using the proposed decision-making method will also increase. Therefore, more accurate prediction of electricity price and PV power is crucial for HEMS agents to make precise and effective decisions. 4.3 Optimization results of the SAC-based DRL decision-making method In this study, we considered two types of non-schedulable loads: refrigerator (REFRIG), light (LIGHT), and two types of time-schedulable loads: dishwasher (DISHW) and washing machine (WH). Each day is divided into 24 scheduling gaps of one hour each, and a cycle of 24 h is used. The demand-side management of power grid is applied with the DR policy of RTP. The specific parameters of the non-schedulable loads, time-schedulable loads and the remaining key devices in the test HEMS are shown in Table 5 , Table 6 and Table 7 , respectively. To reflect the randomness of the household environment, some parameters of household appliances are not fixed values, but random numbers. ϕ a b c d is a truncated normal distribution random number with a mean of a , a variance of b , and upper and lower limits of c and d , respectively. For other parameters, the end working time for the time-schedulable load is set to be before 24:00 every day. Additionally, for the prediction of human thermal comfort, the user is assumed to be a 38-year-old woman, with a metabolic rate of 1.2 met and a clothing thermal resistance of 0.6 clo. The wind speed is set as 0.1 m/s and the relative humidity is set at 60%. The maximum power exchange between HEMS and the power grid is set as P max Grid = − P min Grid = 20 kW . The parameters of the SAC algorithm are set as shown in Table 8 . Both the actor network and the critic network are set to have 3 hidden layers with 64 neurons in each layer. In this study, the dimension of the state is 8 and the dimension of the action is 8. Therefore, the number of neurons in the input layer for the actor network is 8 and the number of output layers is 8. The number of neurons in the input layer for the online and target critic networks is 16 and the number of output layers is 8. 4.3.1 Optimization results with HEMS participating in DR Considering the DR management, the scheduling strategy results for the proposed DRL-based HEMS optimization framework is shown in Fig. 10 . As can be seen from the figure, during the daylight period with more PV power generation (9:00–17:00), the ESS can store the excess energy for later use. However, this is limited by the capacity and charging power of the ESS, not all excess PV output can be stored. In fact, the charge and discharge mode of the ESS is also closely related to the electricity price. Since the sales price coefficient κ is set to 0.05, the system will firstly weigh the benefits between the benefits of electricity sales and utilization of the energy storage; if the power transaction to the grid is not cost-effective, the excess energy will be charged into the ESS; otherwise, if there is still a surplus after the household electricity is used by all the home devices including the ESS, the HEMS will consider selling the excess electricity to the grid. Fig. 11 shows the variation of indoor temperature when our proposed optimization method with DR management is applied to the HEMS. According to the prediction of user thermal comfort based on XGBoost ensemble learning algorithm in Section 3, the HEMS will be able to adjust the indoor temperature individually and intelligently based on the subjective comfort feeling of users and the status of the HVAC system. It can be seen from Fig. 11 that the indoor temperature can be maintained within a relatively comfortable temperature range of 23 °C–25 °C, which proves the effectiveness of the scheduling strategy considering user habits and preferences. Fig. 12 shows the EV charging strategy under DR management. It can be seen that after the EV arrives at home, it will discharge during the time period with higher electricity price, and then charge it during the time period with lower electricity price. Such a strategy achieves the unity of comfort and economy. Fig. 13 shows the charging and discharging strategies of the energy storage system. It can be seen that ESS mainly discharges during the day and charges at night, fully utilizing the low electricity price at night to create revenue. 4.3.2 Comparation results with HEMS not participating in DR Then we make a comparative analysis of the household energy consumption costs for users who participate in DR and those who do not. In the experiment when the user does not participate in DR, the ESS will not be utilized, and the indoor temperature will be set to 24 °C unless the temperature exceeds the adjustable range of the HVAC. Fig. 14 shows the energy consumption of each device under this scenario. It can be observed that the household electricity consumption is concentrated between 18:00 to 20:00, whereas PV only generates real power during daylight hours from 9:00 to 19:00. This disparity makes it difficult for users to make full use of PV output during the day, forcing them to sell excess energy to the power system. When not participating in DR, the peak load reaches 10 kW, which is higher than 9 kW when participating in DR. Such a high peak load is not conducive to the power balance of the power system. Fig. 15 shows the changes of EV'S SOC when the user does not schedule the charging and discharging process of EV. It can be seen that after the EV arrives, it is charged according to the maximum power, regardless of the economic effect, and the SOC state expected by the user can be reached after 4 h. However, 18:00 to 21:00 is the peak of electricity consumption, and the electricity price is expensive. Such a charging strategy will lead to an increase in economic costs. The comparison of experimental results between participating in DR and not participating in DR is shown in the Table 9 . It can be seen that participating in DR can reduce the economic cost of the family at the expense of an appropriate amount of comfort, and achieve the optimal total cost of the family. By participating in DR, users can reduce electricity costs by 17.7% and total costs by 8.4%. 4.3.3 Comparation of different DRL algorithms The proposed optimal decision-making method based on SAC algorithm in this paper is compared with proximal policy optimization (PPO) [56] algorithm and twin-delayed depth deterministic policy gradient (TD3) [57] algorithm under the same experimental conditions. As can be seen from Fig. 16 that the proposed scheduling framework based on the SAC algorithm performs better compared to the PPO and TD3 algorithms, which achieves better convergence. 4.3.4 Comparation results with different thermal comfort thresholds In order to verify that whether the proposed method can make reasonable energy consumption strategies according to different user characteristics and preferences, a comparative study of HEMS scheduling is carried out for thermal comfort thresholds I set HVAC of 0.5, 0.75, 1.25 and 1.5. As shown in Fig. 17 , under different thermal comfort thresholds, the proposed method can maintain a certain heat tolerance range, and the temperature range increases with the increase of the thermal comfort threshold. From Fig. 18 , it can be seen that the average thermal comfort increases with the increase of the threshold. Table 10 shows the electricity cost and comfort cost under different thermal comfort thresholds. It can be seen that as the thermal comfort threshold increases, the electricity cost gradually decreases, while the comfort cost gradually increases. Under the current experimental settings, the total cost decreases with the increase of the tolerable heat threshold, which means that users have reduced the overall cost of the household by sacrificing thermal comfort. 5 Conclusions This paper introduces a data-driven DRL-based HEMS optimization framework that concurrently considers various household appliances to establish a coordinated DR model in the electricity market. To address the high-dimensional comprehensive decision-making problem that characterizes HEMS, along with the attendant uncertainties, this study proposes a novel framework. Specifically, an XGBoost-based thermal comfort evaluation model is introduced to predict uncertain user thermal comfort, while the BiGRU-NN algorithm predicts future electricity price and PV output trends. Finally, the SAC algorithm is employed to determine optimal scheduling decisions for the HEMS. The efficacy of the proposed models and methods is empirically demonstrated through simulation results using real-world data. The main conclusions of this paper are shown below: 1) Various features play a role in the evaluation of human thermal comfort, but none of them is decisive. The evaluation model based on XGBoost algorithm can achieve more accurate prediction compared to RF, SVR and other models, thus providing more accurate comfort cost for HEMS optimization scheduling; 2) By mining the bi-directional information of the data, the BiGRU-NN model proposed in this paper is more accurate in predicting the electricity price and PV output compared to algorithms such as LSTM. 3) The proposed HEMS optimization method based on SAC algorithm can effectively solve the high-dimensional integrated decision-making problem with uncertainty. By participating in DR, the household electricity cost can be reduced by 17.7% and the total cost can be reduced by 8.4%. Future work will aim to integrate more detailed home appliance models and other energy types, such as thermal energy and natural gas consumptions, into the HEMS. Additionally, a sharing framework suitable for cloud computing will be developed to minimize the computational burden on the user side. coredata.dc:description: With the rise in household computing power and the increasing number of smart devices, more and more residents are able to participate in demand response (DR) management through the home energy management system (HEMS). However, HEMS has encountered challenges in developing the most effective energy management strategies, including the complexity of modeling user comfort, uncertainty in electricity price and photovoltaic (PV) output, and the challenge of solving high-dimensional time-coupled decision problems. To address these challenges, a novel data-driven deep reinforcement learning (DRL)-base HEMS optimization framework considering uncertain household parameters is proposed. Firstly, a thermal comfort evaluation model based on integrated learning is proposed. Then, a prediction model based on the bidirectional gated recurrent unit neural network (BiGRU-NN) algorithm is proposed to mine the time series PV output and electricity price data. Finally, combining the PV output and electricity price forecasting, along with the thermal comfort evaluation, an optimal decision-making method based on soft actor-critic (SAC) algorithm for the HEMS is established. The results of numerical experiments show that the proposed method can effectively solve the high-dimensional integrated decision-making problem with uncertainty. By participating in DR, the household electricity cost can be reduced by 17.7% and the total cost can be reduced by 8.4%. Furthermore, the comparison result shows that the method proposed in this paper performs better than the existing optimization models based on proximal policy optimization (PPO) algorithm and twin-delayed depth deterministic policy gradient (TD3) algorithm.
coredata.dc:title: A data-driven DRL-based home energy management system optimization framework considering uncertain household parameters
